questions.question: What is the correct way to declare a variable in C#?

answers.b: int myVariable = 10;

questions.question: Which of the following is used to define a class in C#?

answers.b: interface

questions.question: What is the purpose of the 'using' statement in C#?

answers.b: To create a new object

questions.question: Which keyword is used to inherit a class in C#?

answers.b: extends

questions.question: What is the default access modifier for class members in C#?

answers.b: private

questions.question: Which of the following is NOT a value type in C#?

answers.b: float

questions.question: What is the correct way to create an instance of a class in C#?

answers.b: new MyClass() = myObject;

questions.question: Which keyword is used to define a constant in C#?

answers.b: final

questions.question: What is the purpose of the 'virtual' keyword in C#?

answers.b: To allow a method to be overridden in derived classes
answers.d: To create a final method that cannot be inherited

questions.question: Which of the following is used to handle exceptions in C#?

answers.b: if-else

questions.question: What is the difference between 'ref' and 'out' parameters in C#?

answers.a: 'ref' requires the parameter to be initialized before passing, 'out' does not
answers.b: 'out' requires the parameter to be initialized before passing, 'ref' does not
answers.c: 'ref' can be used with value types only, 'out' with reference types only
answers.d: There is no difference between 'ref' and 'out'

questions.question: Which of the following is true about delegates in C#?

answers.b: Delegates can only point to static methods
answers.d: Delegates cannot be used with anonymous methods

questions.question: What is the purpose of the 'yield' keyword in C#?

answers.b: To pause the execution of a method
answers.c: To return multiple values from a method
answers.d: To implement lazy evaluation in collections

questions.question: Which of the following correctly describes the 'IDisposable' interface?

answers.a: It is used to implement custom exception handling
answers.b: It is used to manage unmanaged resources
answers.c: It is used to define immutable objects
answers.d: It is used to implement multithreading

questions.question: What is the purpose of the 'sealed' keyword in C#?

answers.b: To prevent a class from being inherited

questions.question: Which of the following is true about abstract classes in C#?

answers.b: Abstract classes can contain only abstract methods
answers.d: Abstract classes cannot contain implemented methods

questions.question: What is the purpose of the 'params' keyword in C#?

answers.b: To pass a variable number of arguments to a method

questions.question: Which of the following correctly describes a 'struct' in C#?

answers.b: Structs can inherit from classes
answers.c: Structs can have a parameterless constructor

questions.question: What is the purpose of the 'as' operator in C#?

answers.b: To create an alias for a namespace
answers.c: To perform type conversion that returns null if conversion fails
answers.d: To check if an object is of a specific type

questions.question: Which of the following is true about extension methods in C#?

answers.a: They can be used to add methods to sealed classes
answers.b: They can override existing methods of a class
answers.c: They must be defined in a non-static class
answers.d: They can access private members of the extended type

questions.question: What is the purpose of the 'break' statement in C#?

answers.a: To exit a loop or switch statement
answers.b: To skip the current iteration of a loop

questions.question: Which of the following is used to read console input in C#?

answers.b: Console.Read()

questions.question: What is the purpose of the 'static' keyword in C#?

answers.b: To create an instance variable
answers.c: To create a class-level variable or method

questions.question: Which of the following is NOT a valid access modifier in C#?

answers.b: private

questions.question: What is the purpose of the 'this' keyword in C#?

answers.a: To refer to the current instance of the class
answers.b: To create a new instance of a class
answers.c: To call a base class method

questions.question: What is the difference between 'const' and 'readonly' in C#?

answers.a: 'const' can only be used with value types, 'readonly' with reference types
answers.b: 'const' is evaluated at compile-time, 'readonly' can be set in the constructor
answers.c: 'readonly' can only be used with static fields, 'const' with instance fields
answers.d: There is no difference between 'const' and 'readonly'

questions.question: Which of the following correctly describes the 'finally' block in exception handling?

answers.a: It is executed only if an exception is thrown
answers.b: It is executed only if no exception is thrown
answers.c: It is always executed, whether an exception is thrown or not
answers.d: It is used to throw custom exceptions

questions.question: What is the purpose of the 'nameof' operator in C#?

answers.a: To get the name of a variable, type, or member as a string
answers.b: To create a new namespace
answers.c: To check if a name exists in the current scope
answers.d: To rename a variable or type

questions.question: Which of the following is true about indexers in C#?

answers.a: Indexers can only use integer indices
answers.b: A class can have multiple indexers
answers.d: Indexers must be declared as static

questions.question: What is the purpose of the 'is' operator in C#?

answers.b: To check if an object is of a specific type
answers.c: To create an instance of a type
